awd_titl_txt: Ecological Functions of Algal Neurotoxins- do they interact with Ion Channels and Cellular Signaling in Non-toxic Phytoplankton Species?
awd_abstract_narration:
Some photosynthetic unicellular marine phytoplankton species, including the marine dinoflagellates, are known to produce nuisance or harmful algal blooms (HABs) such as "Red Tides". Of these, several species produce toxins which, under bloom conditions, can have devastating impacts on coastal ecosystems, causing significant economic loss in fisheries and tourism of coastal communities. Moreover, the occurrence of HABs poses significant risk to public health because several human illnesses are associated with exposure to the algal neurotoxins that are produced by these bloom-forming unicellular organisms. The occurrence of HABs is thus presenting a growing global problem for fisheries, aquaculture and public health. The question of why these microscopic algae produce toxins, particularly neurotoxins, has been much debated, yet remains a poorly understood phenomenon. The harmful effects of algal neurotoxins arise because they interact with ion channels and receptors in cell membranes, interfering with conduction of nerve impulses (also known as action potentials) and signaling in animals and humans, thus leading to paralytic, amnesic and diarrhetic shellfish poisonings. Recent biophysical work has demonstrated such ion channels and action potentials are highly evolutionarily conserved, and utilized by a range of unicellular marine organisms, including diatoms, coccolithophores and dinoflagellates themselves. The hypothesis that these may be the most relevant ecological targets for HAB toxins will be investigated. 

The focus of this project is w on Karenia brevis, a species that produces extensive HABs in the Gulf, SE and NE USA. This dinoflagellate produces a range of toxins known as brevetoxins and researchers at the Center for Marine Sciences at the UNC-Wilmington are the world-leading experts on K. brevis and the chemistry of their toxins. In collaboration with this team, experiments will be conducted to advance understanding of why these neurochemicals are produced by dinoflagellates and whether they interact with homologous targets in competing non-toxic micro-plankton.  Using a combination of cell physiology, imaging and biochemical techniques, experiments will be conducted to characterize the cellular ion currents, action potentials and calcium signals in K. brevis themselves before testing effects of brevetoxins, saxitoxins, okadaic acid and domoic acid on K. brevis and non-toxic phytoplankton. The experimental work will provide crucial insight into the sensory biology of toxin producing dinoflagellates and mechanistic insight into how their toxins interact with ecologically relevant targets in the marine ecosystem. 

The outcomes of this project will lead to a better understanding of the factors that regulate HAB bloom dynamics in coastal areas affected by K. brevis, may lead to development of novel biotechnological tools, and will contribute to recent national initiatives related to Oceans and Human Health.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The harmful effects of neurotoxic algal secondary metabolites arise because they interact with ion channels and receptors, causing membrane depolarisation, Ca2+ influx and interference with conduction of nerve impulses in animals and humans. Harmful algal blooms therefore pose significant risk to public health because several human illnesses are associated with exposure to their algal toxins.  In spite of the potentially severe consequences on humans and animals, the ecological role of toxin production by harmful algae remains unclear. A proposed function is that toxins play a role in enhanced interspecific competition among marine microbial species. This project therefore examined the impact of algal toxins, known to affect ion channels and signalling in animals, on marine protist membrane physiology and signalling. Two major hypotheses were tested. First, that algal toxins exert an alleopathic effect by interaction with ion channels and signalling pathways in non-toxic marine protist species. Second, that toxic dinoflagellates possess similar, highly conserved ion channels and sensory mechanisms that are insensitive to their own toxins.  

The results from the project demonstrated that brevetoxin only had an effect on Na+ currents of non-toxic phytoplankton at very high concentrations. Thus, while non-toxic phytoplankton possess similar voltage active ion channels to higher organisms, they are unaffected at ecologically relevant concentrations of this harmful algal toxin. The results led to significant new data on the uptake and vectoring of harmful toxins, showing that some taxa of non-toxic marine microbes (e.g. cyanobacteria, dinoflagellates, cryptophytes) are resistant to taking up these lipophyllic toxins whereas others (diatoms, microzooplankton, microcrustaceans) rapidly accumulate them. This implies that co-occurring organisms can accumulate and passively vector toxins in the marine microbial web, representing a significant pathway for trophic transfer of bloom toxins not previously recognized. Interestingly, the brevetoxin producing dinoflagellate (Karenia brevis) did not absorb exogenously applied brevetoxin, and is therefore unaffected by water-born brevetoxins released during blooms. Of the phytoplankton that did absorb brevetoxin, significant variation in the toxin binding site of their Na+ channels is the likely cause of insensitivity. A further mechanism of insensitivity is the discovery that some protists (e.g. the diatom Odontella sinensis) have lost the animal-like Na+ channel from the genome, but acquired bacterial-like Na+ channels through horizontal gene transfer that could functionally substitute for the eukaryote channel yet is completely insensitive to the toxin.  

In addition to successfully addressing the central hypotheses of the proposal, the project yielded additional important findings. Notably, that coccolithophores and diatoms possess animal-like voltage activated H+ channels (Hv1) that play a significant role in regulating cellular pH. This shows the Hv1 class of ion channels, previously only characterized in mammals, evolved in ancestral eukaryotes and are widely distributed amongst diverse extant eukaryotes.

Other significant advances included work to marine ciliates that are important microzooplankton grazers of phytoplankton and therefore a potential target for a wide range of toxins and allelochemicals in the marine ecosystem. The first ever simultaneous electrophysiological recording and high speed imaging were acheived in a marine pelagic ciliate Favella sp. and yielded highly novel data on the bioelectrical regulation of swimming, feeding and escape in this key marine microbial group.
